# A Two-Hundred-Year-Old Book on Sheep Breeding

Everything is on the internet... even a scan of an almost two-hundred-year-old book on sheep breeding... and why such a book?

## Research for the Novel

Well, wanting to write the story of Bethlehem shepherds, I decided I needed to learn something about their work. The problem is that this work two thousand years ago probably looked somewhat different than now.

So I had to reach as far into the past as possible and looked for information about what sheep breeding looked like in ancient times. This is how I came across Mr. Kurowski's book, whose writing style I really liked, so much that I read almost all of it ðŸ˜Š

## Sheep in The Stick and the Carrot

Everything in my novel "The Stick and the Carrot" concerning shepherds and sheep is drawn from or inspired by Mr. Kurowski's knowledge, to whom I hereby give thanks. Although of course my book doesn't focus on sheep, but on Christmas.

## Quote

Those interested I refer to the Digital Repository of Scientific Institutes for this and other treasures ([rcin.org.pl](http://rcin.org.pl)). For a taste, a quote from Mr. Kurowski:

> "Now these are the qualities of a good shepherd. Now I will present to you in general how to recognize him; and how one immediately recognizes a bad shepherd, or bungler, such as unfortunately occur most often. First of all, I consider a shepherd a bungler if, when I enter his sheepfold, the air stings my eyes so much that it brings tears. Secondly. No better than the first is one whose sheepfold when you enter not during feeding time, the sheep start bleating at the top of their lungs: for this is unmistakable proof that he does not maintain a certain order in grazing sheep."

(oh, Mr. Kurowski was apparently one of the first self-publishers because further on the title pages it says it was published at the author's own expense ðŸ˜‰)
